text: The Parable of the Ten Virgins

“Then the kingdom of heaven may be compared to ten virgins who took their lamps \add and\add*\ef + \fr 25:1 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“took”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* went out to meet the bridegroom.
Now five of them were foolish and five \add were\add* wise.

For \add when\add*\ef + \fr 25:3 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“took”) which is understood as temporal \ef* the foolish ones took their lamps, they did not take olive oil with them.
But the wise ones took olive oil in flasks with their lamps.

And \add when\add*\ef + \fr 25:5 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the temporal genitive absolute participle (“was delayed”) \ef* the bridegroom was delayed, they all became drowsy and fell asleep.\f + \fr 25:5 \ft The imperfect tense has been translated as ingressive here (“began to sleep”, “fell asleep”) \f*
But in the middle of the night there was a shout, ‘Behold, the bridegroom! Come out to meet him!’
Then all those virgins woke up and trimmed their lamps.
And the foolish ones said to the wise ones, ‘Give us \add some\add* of your olive oil, because our lamps are going out!’

But the wise ones answered saying, “Certainly there will never be enough for us and for you! Go instead to those who sell \add olive oil\add*\ef + \fr 25:9 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* and buy \add some\add*\ef + \fr 25:9 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* for yourselves.’

But \add while\add*\ef + \fr 25:10 \ft ﻿*Here “\add while\add*” is supplied as a component of the temporal genitive absolute participle (“had gone away”) \ef* they had gone away to buy \add it\add*\ef + \fr 25:10 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* the bridegroom arrived, and those who were ready went inside with him to the wedding celebration, and the door was shut.
And later the other virgins came also, saying, ‘Lord, lord, open \add the door\add*\ef + \fr 25:11 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* for us!’

But he answered \add and\add*\ef + \fr 25:12 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“answered”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* said, ‘Truly I say to you, I do not know you!’
Therefore be on the alert, because you do not know the day or the hour!
The Parable of the Talents
For \add it is\add* like a man going on a journey. He summoned his own slaves and handed over his property to them.
And to one he gave five talents, and to another two, and to another one, to each one according to his own ability, and he went on a journey immediately.

The one who had received the five talents went out \add and\add*\ef + \fr 25:16 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“went out”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* traded with them and gained five more.
In the same way the one \add who had\add* the two gained two more.

But the one who had received the one went away \add and\add*\ef + \fr 25:18 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“went away”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* dug up the ground and hid his master’s money.
Now after a long time, the master of those slaves came and settled accounts with them.

And the one who had received the five talents came up \add and\add*\ef + \fr 25:20 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“came up”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* brought five more talents, saying, ‘Master, you handed over to me five talents. See, I have gained five more talents!’

His master said to him, ‘Well done, good and faithful slave! You were faithful over a few \add things\add*; I will put you \add in charge\add* over many \add things\add*. Enter into the joy of your master!’

And the one \add who had\add* the two talents also came up \add and\add*\ef + \fr 25:22 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“came up”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* said, ‘Master, you handed over to me two talents. See, I have gained two talents more!’

His master said to him, ‘Well done, good and faithful slave! You were faithful over a few \add things\add*; I will put you \add in charge\add* over many \add things\add*. Enter into the joy of your master!’

And the one who had received the one talent came up also \add and\add*\ef + \fr 25:24 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“came up”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* said, ‘Master, \add because I\add*\ef + \fr 25:24 \ft ﻿*Here “\add because\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“knew”) which is understood as causal \ef* knew you, that you are a hard man, reaping where you did not sow and gathering from where you did not scatter \add seed\add*.\ef + \fr 25:24 \ft *Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef*

And \add because I\add*\ef + \fr 25:25 \ft ﻿*Here “\add because\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“was afraid”) which is understood as causal \ef* was afraid, I went away \add and\add*\ef + \fr 25:25 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“went away”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* hid your talent in the ground. See, you have \add what is\add* yours!’

But his master answered \add and\add*\ef + \fr 25:26 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“answered”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* said to him, ‘Evil and lazy slave! You knew that I reap where I did not sow and gather from where I did not scatter \add seed\add*.\ef + \fr 25:26 \ft *Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef*

Then you ought to have deposited my money with the bankers, and \add when I\add*\ef + \fr 25:27 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“returned”) which is understood as temporal \ef* returned I would have gotten back \add what was\add* mine with interest!
Therefore take the talent from him and give \add it\add*\ef + \fr 25:28 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to the one who has the ten talents.
For to everyone who has, \add more\add* will be given, and he will have an abundance. But from the one who does not have, even what he has will be taken away from him.
And throw the worthless slave into the outer darkness—in that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth!’
The Judgment of the Sheep and the Goats
Now when the Son of Man comes in his glory and all the angels with him, then he will sit on his glorious throne.
And all the nations will be gathered before him, and he will separate them from one another like a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.
And he will place the sheep on his right and the goats on the left.
Then the king will say to those on his right, ‘Come, \add you\add* who are blessed by my Father. Inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world!

For I was hungry and you gave me \add something\add*\ef + \fr 25:35 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to eat, I was thirsty and you gave me \add something\add*\ef + \fr 25:35 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to drink, I was a stranger and you welcomed me as a guest,
I was naked and you clothed me, I was sick and you cared for me, I was in prison and you came to me.’

Then the righteous will answer him, saying, ‘Lord, when did we see you hungry and feed \add you\add*,\ef + \fr 25:37 \ft *Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* or thirsty and give \add you something\add*\ef + \fr 25:37 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to drink?

And when did we see you a stranger and welcome \add you\add*\ef + \fr 25:38 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* as a guest, or naked and clothe \add you\add*?\ef + \fr 25:38 \ft *Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef*
And when did we see you sick or in prison and come to you?’

And the king will answer \add and\add*\ef + \fr 25:40 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“will answer”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* say to them, ‘Truly I say to you, in as much as you did \add it\add*\ef + \fr 25:40 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to one of the least of these brothers of mine, you did \add it\add*\ef + \fr 25:40 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to me.’
Then he will also say to those on \add his\add* left, ‘Depart from me, \add you\add* accursed ones, into the eternal fire that has been prepared for the devil and his angels!

For I was hungry and you did not give me \add anything\add*\ef + \fr 25:42 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to eat, I was thirsty and you did not give me \add anything\add*\ef + \fr 25:42 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to drink,
I was a stranger and you did not welcome me as a guest, naked and you did not clothe me, sick and in prison and you did not care for me.’
Then they will also answer, saying, ‘Lord, when did we see you hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison and not serve you?’

Then he will answer them, saying, ‘Truly I say to you, in as much as you did not do \add it\add*\ef + \fr 25:45 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to one of the least of these, you did not do \add it\add*\ef + \fr 25:45 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to me.’
And these will depart into eternal punishment, but the righteous into eternal life.”
